com.github.thorbenkuck.netcom2.network.shared.clients

Interface Client


  • public interface Client
    An Client is an Object-Representation of a physical Computer, connected via one or multiple Socket.

    The Client encapsulates information needed for the Client-Server-Communication, such as:

    • Connections this Computer uses
    • A Session, shared across all active Connections
    • A Disconnected Handler
    • The CommunicationRegistration

    The client has multiple methods, that are required for the internal Mechanisms, so that the default behaviour is working. Especially Connections, Serialization, Encryption, Primed and FalseIDs are core elements for the internal Mechanisms.

    It is highly discouraged to create custom Client-Objects.

    The Client is created, once a Socket connects and maintained within the ClientList

    Most of the Time, you do not need to do anything with this class, except for setting Encryption or Synchronization. Some of the Methods are highly risky to use, except if followed by a certain other call.

    Version 1.1:

    With version 1.1, the Serialization and Encryption mechanisms, are decoupled into the ObjectHandler.

    The Connection management also has been overhauled. A Client now is considered primed, as soon as the DefaultConnection is established.

    All currently deprecated methods will be removed in the next major update.

    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    1.1
    See Also:
    Session, CommunicationRegistration, ObjectHandler

      • removeConnection

        void removeConnection(Connection connection)
        Removes a Connection from the internally maintained ConnectionMap.

        This is only needed, if you manually add a Connection to the Client.

        Parameters:
        connection - the Connection, that should be removed

      • addConnection

        void addConnection(Connection connection)
        Adds a connection.

        Internally it uses the setConnection(Class, Connection) method, based on the Connection.getIdentifier() value.

        Parameters:
        connection - the Connection, that should be added.

      • setConnection

        void setConnection(Class<?> identifier,
                   Connection connection)
        Safes an connection for this Client.

        Neither the provided key, nor the Connection itself might be null. The Connection will than be able to be used by send(Class, Object) or getConnection(Class). If you insert a custom Connection here, you will have to ensure, that this Connection is correctly established. This method does not ensure, that the Connection is correctly established.

        The Connection might be of any Type (Client-Server, File, or anything similar), but it must be active if set.

        Also you might rout any other Connection by setting an already existing Connection to a new Key. For Example: client.getConnection(FirstKey.class).ifPresent(connection - client.setConnection(SecondKey.class, connection));

        This will allow the connection to be used / retrieved by both:

        client.getConnection(FirstKey.class).get(); client.getConnection(SecondKey.class).get();

        An both will result in the same Connection

        Parameters:
        identifier - the key, through which the Connection can be used
        connection - the Connection, that should be used, when asked for the Connection

      • routeConnection

        void routeConnection(Class originalKey,
                     Class newKey)
        Searches for the set Connections for the originalKey.
        Parameters:
        originalKey - a key, the chosen Connection is set to
        newKey - the new key, which this Connection should be accessible through
        See Also:
        routeConnection(Connection, Class)

      • routeConnection

        void routeConnection(Connection originalConnection,
                     Class newKey)
        This Method routs an given Connection to an new Key.

        The Original Connection will not be unbound from its current bound. This means, that after calling this method, the given Connection is accessible via both, its original Key and the newKey.

        A Connection might be routed to any number of keys. So one Connection can be accessible by any number of calls.

        Other than setConnection(Class, Connection) a "null-route" is possible, to allow an sort of "fallback-route".

        If you use: client.routConnection(OriginalKey.class, null); a warning will be logged via the Logging and the Connection is used, whenever you state: client.send(new MessageObject(), null);

        This might be useful, if you calculate the Keys at runtime. However, it is discouraged to trigger a null-route by stating null at compile time.

        Implementing aspects: Implementing this Method should not lead to an duplication of this Connection. The route should be implemented the same way, the original Connection setting was.

        Further should this rout be accessible by "not complex calculations" (negative example: setting it inside the Connection and than iterating over all Connection, comparing each set Key inside this Connection to find each corresponding Connection).

        Parameters:
        originalConnection - the Connection that should be rerouted
        newKey - the new key, under which the given Connection is accessible

      • getConnection

        Optional<Connection> getConnection(Class connectionKey)
        Returns an respective Connection for a given ConnectionKey.

        Since this Connection might not (yet) exist, it is wrapped in an Optional.

        Parameters:
        connectionKey - the Key for the Connection
        Returns:
        the Optional.of(connection for connectionKey)

      • disconnect

        void disconnect()
        This Method cuts all Connections.

        In detail: it closes all Connections, created at any point in time, and afterwards clears the list which those where kept in. After all Connections are closed, the disconnected handler will be called in an descending order of how they where added Each of the ClientDisconnectedHandler will be called.

        Lastly the ClientID will be set to an ClientID.empty() and the Session will be recreated

        Calling this method is not reversible! Once closed, it cannot be reopened easily. The only way would be, to manually recreate all Connections, required for this Client to function. So calling this method manually is discouraged

        That being said, this Method is called by the ClientStart, if the Server disconnects after an Connection has been established. Internally this is done, to prevent calculations to recreate the Client once this ClientStart reconnects.

        This will disconnect the ClientStart and ServerStart respectively.

        Note: The behaviour of this Method changed in V.1.1. It will now trigger a pipeline, containing the disconnected Handler.

      • getSession

        Session getSession()
        Returns the internal Session for this Client. The Session is created upon calling setup(). The Client knows of its Session, but the Session does not knows of its Client. The Session however uses an SendBridge which is individual for each Client. Therefor every Session is unique for every Client, even tho multiple Session may have the same attribute.
        Returns:
        the internally set Session
        See Also:
        Session

      • setSession

        void setSession(Session session)
        Sets the internal Session, overriding any previously set instances.
        Parameters:
        session - the current internal set Session or null.

      • primed

        com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.sync.Awaiting primed()
        Returns an Awaiting instance over the primed state

        This Awaiting will block, until the defaultConnection is established

        Returns:
        a Awaiting instance

      • isPrimed

        boolean isPrimed()
        Describes whether or not this Client is primed.
        Returns:
        true if this Client is primed, else false

      • triggerPrimed

        void triggerPrimed()
        Triggers the primed state of this Client.

        You may call this at any time, but you should not. This will be called automatically, once the DefaultConnection is established.

        If this client is already primed, this call is ignored.

      • getID

        ClientID getID()
        Returns the ClientID for this Client

        This Method will never Return null and is controlled by setID(ClientID)

        Returns:
        the ClientID for this Client

      • setID

        void setID(ClientID id)
        Sets the ClientID for this client.

        This might not be null and will throw an IllegalArgumentException if null is provided. You can certainly call this method, but it is highly discouraged to do so. The idea of this method is, to manually override the ClientID of false Clients, created via a new Connection creation.

        Parameters:
        id - the new ID for this client
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if id == null

      • addDisconnectedHandler

        void addDisconnectedHandler(ClientDisconnectedHandler disconnectedHandler)
        Adds an ClientDisconnectedHandler to this Client, which is called if this Client disconnects from the ClientStart or ServerStart respectively.

        The DisconnectedHandler is therefore a CallBackObject.

        Note: Previously, this Method expected a DisconnectedHandler. We now use a ClientDisconnectedHandler, because it inherits from Consumer and may easily be added to a Pipeline, without the need of a wrapper

        Parameters:
        disconnectedHandler - an instance of an DisconnectedHandler.

      • removeDisconnectedHandler

        void removeDisconnectedHandler(ClientDisconnectedHandler disconnectedHandler)

      • addPrimedCallback

      • objectHandler

        ObjectHandler objectHandler()

      • sendIgnoreConstraints

        void sendIgnoreConstraints(Object object,
                           Connection connection)
        Whilst the other send Methods wait for the Connection to de block Connection.connected(), this method ignores this.

        Some times it is needed, but most of the time, this is not what you want. Instead, try to use send(Object, Class), send(Object, Connection) or send(Object).

        The Connection.connected() Awaiting blocks until the internal default CommunicationProtocol is finished. Only then it is ensured, that the Server or the Client knows exactly what this Connection is associated with.

        Parameters:
        object - the Object to send over the Connection
        connection - the Connection to send the Object to

      • send

        void send(Object object,
          Connection connection)
        Behaves similar to the send(Object) method with the exception, that it takes the concrete Connection the given Object should be send over.

        This Method is the exit-point of every other send call.

        Parameters:
        connection - the Connection the Object should be send over
        object - the Object to be send over the Connection, must meet the Connection requirements to be send successfully
        See Also:
        send(Object)

      • send

        void send(Object object,
          Class<?> connectionKey)
        Behaves similar to the send(Object) method with the exception, that it takes the connectionKey of an existing Connection to be send over this Connection instead.

        Note: Previously, this method returned a ReceiveOrSendSynchronization. This is no longer the case.

        Parameters:
        object - the Object to be send over the Connection, must meet the Connection requirements to be send successfully
        connectionKey - the Key of the Connection, this object should be send over
        See Also:
        send(Object)

      • send

        void send(Object object)
        This Method will try to send an Object over an Connection.

        Since this Method takes no identifier parameter for the Connection, it uses the DefaultConnection to Send the method. This Method returns nearly immediately. Further, an Object is considered "send" if the Connection accepts the Object.

        In the new Design, this method ultimately extracts a new Task into the NetComThreadPool using NetComThreadPool.submitTask(Runnable). If you experience to slow processing, call NetComThreadPool.startWorkerProcess() to start a new Worker.

        Note: Previously, this method returned a ReceiveOrSendSynchronization. This is no longer the case.

        Parameters:
        object - the Object to be send over the Connection, must meet the Connection requirements to be send successfully
        See Also:
        NetComThreadPool.submitTask(Runnable), NetComThreadPool.startWorkerProcess()

      • getFormattedAddress

        String getFormattedAddress()
        Returns the formatted address for this Client.

        This is only used for printing and in the following form:

        inetAddress() + ":" + port

        Returns:
        the formatted Address of this Client.

      • overridePrepareConnection

      • accessPrepareConnection

        com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.sync.Synchronize accessPrepareConnection(Class clazz)

      • prepareConnection

        com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.sync.Awaiting prepareConnection(Class clazz)
        Prepares a Connection to be established soon.

        This method creates an internal Awaiting, to be used, to synchronize until the given Connection is established. You can manually use this Method, to ensure any Connection you manually establish is set and ready to go.

        If your Manual Connection is ready to go, the method notifyAboutPreparedConnection(Class). This will release any Threads, waiting for the establishment of said Connection.

        Please note, that this method should be called with care. If you prepare an Connection, that is already established you might screw up the internal Mechanisms"

        Also note that you do not have to call this method, if you use the createNewConnection(Class) method. Upon calling the createNewConnection(Class) the internal Mechanisms will sooner or later call this method to create an Awaiting to synchronize Threads, waiting for this Connection.

        Do not cast this return value to an Synchronize! The instance of the Awaiting is depending on the Implementation of the Client.

        Parameters:
        clazz - the key for the new Connection, that is going to be established
        Returns:
        the Awaiting to synchronize and wait for the Connection to be established.

      • createNewConnection

        default com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.sync.Awaiting createNewConnection(Class connectionKey)
        Creates an new Connection based upon an Class.

        A call on the ServerStart will result in an Request to create a new Connection on the ClientStart. A call on the ClientStart will result in an Request to ask to create a new Connection on the ServerStart which is functionally equal to this call on the ServerStart

        Once the Request ist send from the ServerStart to the ClientStart, a new physical connection is going to be established. This whole Process is completely Asynchronous and can be synchronized using the returned Awaiting.synchronize().

        This results in an long Request-Response-Chain from ClientStart to ServerStart. On the end of this Chain, the returned Awaiting is triggered to continue and the Connection is ready to be used.

        The key is an Class, so that it is assured it can be send over the Network.

        Parameters:
        connectionKey - a Class as an key to identify the Connection.
        Returns:
        an Awaiting that continues if the Connection is established and primed.

      • connectionPrepared

        void connectionPrepared(Class<?> identifier)

      • invalidate

        void invalidate()

      • setThreadPool

        @Deprecated
default void setThreadPool(ExecutorService executorService)
        Deprecated. The Client will no longer manually create Threads. It uses NetComThreadPool
        This Method is meant for providing an custom ExecutorService to be used within every subclass of the Client.

        For example the Connection provides a method to override the existing ThreadPool.

        WARNING! This Method is extremely workload intensive! For this Method to work correctly, all current Runnable have to be stopped and than the current ExecutorService has to be shutdown. This procedure is repeated for each subclass, like the Connections. In this Time-Frame all {} and {} will be stopped, which will lead to an shut down communication during the time the ExecutorService is swapped!

        Parameters:
        executorService - the new ExecutorService to be used within every sub class.

      • setup

        @Deprecated
default void setup()
        Deprecated. Old Design. Use triggerPrimed() upon first Connection creation
        This Method initially sets up the Client.

        It creates a new Session and potentially overrides the existing one. Calling this Method might be a bad idea. It certainly is possible to call this Method at runtime, but the Session has to be passed to every Connection.

        Further: You should call client.getSession().triggerPrimation() after the this method returns. The new Session, now associated after this method finishes, is NOT primed.

        Also, if you call this method during an Connection establishment or anything similar, you might screw up the currently running Mechanism, which requires the Session.

        This method is to be understood as the initial setup of an Client. It is called upon its creation and not again later.

        Implementation Aspects: Call this Method within the constructor, or make clear, that it has to be called as soon as possible. Further you might disable any other call, after the first.

      • triggerPrimation

        @Deprecated
default void triggerPrimation()
        Deprecated. use triggerPrimed()
        See Also:
        Session.triggerPrimation()

      • newPrimation

        @Deprecated
default void newPrimation()
        Deprecated. 
        See Also:
        Session.newPrimation()

      • clearSession

        @Deprecated
default void clearSession()
        Deprecated. 
        Deletes the internal Session.

        The Session will be set to null! This is important! If you call this method getSession() WILL return null!

        You should ONLY call this method, if you experience difficulties or something similar whenever an Client disconnects. Otherwise you will get a LOT of NullPointerException from nearly everywhere inside NetCom2.

        This method is called by the DefaultClientDisconnectedHandler to reset the internal Client from within the ClientStart so that you might reconnect and reuse this client. At the ServerSide this will lead to problems.

        To counterweight the call of clear Session you might call setup(), to set a new Session instance.

      • getMainSerializationAdapter

default SerializationAdapter getMainSerializationAdapter()
        Deprecated. has been relocated to the ObjectHandler

        the set MainSerializationAdapter
        See Also:

      • setMainSerializationAdapter

        @Deprecated
default void setMainSerializationAdapter(SerializationAdapter mainSerializationAdapter)
        Deprecated. has been relocated to the ObjectHandler
        Sets the Main-SerializationAdapter to be used by the Connection, encapsulated by this Client.

        This will take the object, that should be send over the chosen Connection and turns it into an String. This String is than send over the Network and then DeSerialized, using the setMainDeSerializationAdapter(DeSerializationAdapter).

        The String should be reversibly serialized, so that it can be turned back into an Object with its current state.

        Parameters:
        mainSerializationAdapter - the new MainSerializationAdapter

      • getMainDeSerializationAdapter

        @Deprecated
default DeSerializationAdapter getMainDeSerializationAdapter()
        Deprecated. has been relocated to the ObjectHandler
        Returns:
        the set MainDeSerializationAdapter
        See Also:
        setMainDeSerializationAdapter(DeSerializationAdapter)

      • setMainDeSerializationAdapter

        @Deprecated
default void setMainDeSerializationAdapter(DeSerializationAdapter mainDeSerializationAdapter)
        Deprecated. has been relocated to the ObjectHandler
        Sets the Main-DeSerializationAdapter to be used by the Connection, encapsulated by this Client.

        This will take the string, that was received over an Connection and turns it into an Object, which is than passed anto the CommunicationRegistration. This String was formally serialized using the setMainSerializationAdapter(SerializationAdapter).

        Parameters:
        mainDeSerializationAdapter - the new Main-DeSerializationAdapter

      • setEncryptionAdapter

        @Deprecated
default void setEncryptionAdapter(EncryptionAdapter encryptionAdapter)
        Deprecated. has been relocated to the ObjectHandler
        Sets an EncryptionAdapter to be used to encrypt strings after they were serialized using an SerializationAdapter.

        This encryption should be reversibly, so that it can be turned back into its original state using the DecryptionAdapter.

        Parameters:
        encryptionAdapter - the EncryptionAdapter that should be used in all Connection of this Client

      • isConnectionPrepared

        @Deprecated
default boolean isConnectionPrepared(Class clazz)
        Deprecated. 
        Returns, whether or not an Connection is prepared.

        This Method will return true, if an Connection is prepared, but not yet established. You can prepare an connection by calling prepareConnection(Class). You can release the prepared part, by calling notifyAboutPreparedConnection(Class). Once you called this Method, the internal Awaiting will continue and not be safed any longer.

        Tho you can save the Awaiting, returned by prepareConnection(Class), it is discouraged. It will be cleared automatically

        Parameters:
        clazz - the identifier of the Connection
        Returns:
        whether or not the Connection is prepared but not released

      • notifyAboutPreparedConnection

        @Deprecated
default void notifyAboutPreparedConnection(Class clazz)
        Deprecated. 
        Releases the internal Awaiting instance, waiting for any Connection prepared, identified by the parameter.

        You can access the Awaiting by calling prepareConnection(Class) with the same class. It will return the corresponding Awaiting.

        Parameters:
        clazz - the Class
        See Also:

        This Method may release the internal {@link Awaiting}, but the implementation of the Awaiting is defined by the implementation of this Client.

      • addFalseID

        @Deprecated
default void addFalseID(ClientID clientID)
        Deprecated. 
        Adds an faulty ID, that this Client is falsely associated with.

        It is recommended to not use this Method. This Method is required, by the internal Mechanism to create and establish new Connections.

        Since the establishment of a new Connection means the establishment of a new Socket, a new Client is falsely create for each new Connection. Those Clients need to be deleted at from the ClientList, these ClientID added this way, are used to find those false Clients.

        Therefor the correct Client will encapsulate all false ClientIDs.

        Parameters:
        clientID - the ClientID of an Client, that was created falsely

      • getFalseIDs

        @Deprecated
default List<ClientID> getFalseIDs()
        Deprecated. 
        Returns all false ClientID.
        Returns:
        a List of all ClientIDs, identifying false Clients
        See Also:
        addFalseID(ClientID)

      • removeFalseID

        @Deprecated
default void removeFalseID(ClientID clientID)
        Deprecated. 
        Removes a false ID from this Client.
        Parameters:
        clientID - the ClientID, that should be removed
        See Also:
        addFalseID(ClientID)

      • removeFalseIDs

        @Deprecated
default void removeFalseIDs(List<ClientID> clientIDS)
        Deprecated. 
        Removes all given false IDs from this Client.
        Parameters:
        clientIDS - a list, containing ClientIDs, that should be removed
        See Also:
        removeFalseID(ClientID)
